title: Getting Started with epidscan
text: epidscan built around core ideas: Stateless design: hidden global state. Every function call independent reproducible. Input validation happens upfront rather runtime. Type-safe inputs: ss_tbl system validates data structure analysis runs. Location IDs, coordinates, time formats checked construction time. Spatial-first: Native support sf objects. Coordinate system detection ordering handled automatically. Parameter transparency: Three-level parameter hierarchy (data defaults → function overrides → template files) makes configuration explicit traceable.

title: SaTScan Parameter Reference
text: parameters define data files required SaTScan. CaseFile: Path case file. Contains location IDs, case counts, optionally time covariates. ControlFile: Path control file (required Bernoulli model). Contains location IDs control counts. PopulationFile: Path population file (required Poisson model). Contains location IDs, time, population counts, optional covariates. CoordinatesFile: Path coordinates file. Contains location IDs X/Y Lat/Long coordinates. 0 = None (purely spatial analysis) 1 = Year 2 = Month 3 = Day 4 = Generic (arbitrary numeric units) StartDate: Study period start date (format: YYYY/MM/DD). EndDate: Study period end date (format: YYYY/MM/DD). UseGridFile: Use custom grid file instead using case locations centers? (y/n) GridFile: Path grid file. Optional file specifying alternative cluster center points. 0 = Cartesian (X, Y arbitrary units like meters) 1 = Latitude/Longitude (geodetic, requires WGS84-like coordinates)

title: SaTScan Parameter Reference
text: Core analysis settings including type model. 1 = Purely Spatial: Finds geographic clusters ignoring time. 2 = Purely Temporal: Finds time clusters ignoring geography. 3 = Retrospective Space-Time: Finds space-time clusters historical data. 4 = Prospective Space-Time: Surveillance mode, clusters must include current time. 5 = Spatial Variation Temporal Trends: Finds areas different time trends (Poisson ). 6 = Prospective Purely Temporal: Temporal surveillance, cluster must end current time. 7 = Seasonal Temporal: Finds recurring seasonal patterns (Dec 31 wraps Jan 1). 0 = Discrete Poisson: count data known background population. Fast. 1 = Bernoulli: case/control data (0/1). Requires control file. 2 = Space-Time Permutation: Case-data, adjusts purely spatial/temporal patterns. 3 = Ordinal: ordered categorical outcomes (e.g., cancer stage /II/III). 4 = Exponential: survival time data (censoring). 5 = Normal: continuous data (e.g., birth weight). Sensitive outliers. 6 = Continuous Poisson: point process data observations can occur anywhere. 7 = Multinomial: unordered categorical outcomes (e.g., disease subtypes). 8 = Rank: Non-parametric rank-based model. 9 = UniformTime: Uniform temporal model. 10 = Batched: batched data analysis. 1 = High Rates (Poisson/Bernoulli/STP), High Values (Ordinal/Normal), Short Survival (Exponential) 2 = Low Rates/Values, Long Survival 3 = High Low (recommended unbiased analysis) TimeAggregationUnits: Units aggregating time (0=None, 1=Year, 2=Month, 3=Day, 4=Generic). TimeAggregationLength: Number time units per aggregation period (positive integer).

title: Run SaTScan Analysis — satscanr
text: SaTScan (short): SaTScan detects evaluates clusters scanning many candidate windows across space, time, space-time. candidate window, computes probability-model-specific likelihood ratio (analogous test statistic) comparing risk inside window versus outside. window maximum statistic reported likely cluster. Statistical significance typically assessed Monte Carlo simulation null, repeating scan obtain null distribution maximum statistic. Probability models: likelihood/test statistic depends ModelType (e.g., discrete Poisson, Bernoulli, space-time permutation, multinomial, ordinal, exponential, normal). function delegates inferential details SaTScan executable; documentation summarizes general workflow. Example (discrete Poisson; high-rate scanning): Let \(C\) total cases, \(c\) observed cases inside window, \(E\) expected cases inside window null (possibly covariate-adjusted). commonly reported likelihood ratio form proportional : $$ \Lambda = \left(\frac{c}{E}\right)^{c} \left(\frac{C-c}{C-E}\right)^{C-c} \cdot \mathbb{}(c > E) $$ \(\mathbb{}(c > E)\) enforces "high-rate" constraint. (low-rate two-sided scanning, indicator rule differs; see SaTScan User Guide.) Example (Bernoulli; high-rate scanning): Let \(C\) total cases, \(c\) cases inside window, \(N\) total observations (cases + controls), \(n\) observations inside window. SaTScan uses analogous likelihood ratio based -window vs --window case proportions. User guide: full details model-specific likelihoods, scanning windows, parameter definitions, see SaTScan technical documentation (includes User Guide PDF): https://www.satscan.org/techdoc.html
